title: Trending: Burl Wood Furniture & Accents
description: Burl wood is a unique yet recognizable pattern that’s trending in design. author: Kate Riley
excerpt: Burl wood is a unique yet recognizable pattern that’s trending in design. Burl wood has been used in antiques for centuries but is captivating interior desi ...
text: Burl wood is a unique yet recognizable pattern that’s trending in design. Burl wood has been used in antiques for centuries but is captivating interior designers and furniture makers yet again, popping up everywhere in retail and in the online marketplace. burl wood media console Burl wood has a distinct appearance, it originates inside a tree’s growth, known as a burl, that forms on the trunk or branches of a tree. These growths occur when the tree undergoes stress or injury, such as from a virus, fungus, or physical damage. As a result, the grain patterns in burl wood are twisted and intricate forming often unpredictable designs prized for their aesthetic qualities. These patterns can range from swirls and eyes to waves and knots, making each piece of burl wood one of a kind. burl wood side table  Burl wood can be harvested from a variety of tree species, including walnut, maple, oak, redwood, and elm. Each type of wood offers its own unique color and grain characteristics, further adding to the material’s allure. burl wood chest of drawers Historically, burl wood has been a desirable material in the creation of fine furniture and decorative objects. During the 18th and 19th centuries, it was particularly popular in Europe, where it was used to create luxurious furniture pieces for the wealthy. Craftsman of that day would use veneers of burl wood to adorn cabinets and tables since the intricate grain patterns were a mark of sophistication and status. The use of burl wood extended to China and beyond, in the Far East it was harmonious with the principles of organic forms and nature. In the antiques arena, burl wood pieces are pricey and sought after by collectors for their historical significance and unique beauty. The rarity of burl wood, combined with the skill required to work with it, makes antique burl wood pieces particularly valuable. three drawer dresser Burl wood has made a comeback in modern interiors. As the appeal of using organic materials continues to grow, so does the appreciation for craftsmanship and the use of natural materials in creating statement pieces. burl wood coffee table Furniture continues to be one of the most popular uses of burl wood to create eye catching focal points in living spaces, larger pieces can fetch high prices. burl wood dresser The ability of burl wood to seamlessly blend with both modern and traditional aesthetics makes it a versatile choice for a wide range of design styles. parsons console Because burl wood is often harvested from trees that are already damaged or diseased, its use does not contribute to deforestation so it is valued for its sustainability. Burl wood offers both craftsmanship and rarity which makes it a material that feels special, distinctive, and timeless. rounded corner desk burl wood box I love burl wood, but its price point is high and I’m not in the market for any pieces at this time. I’m going to experiment with a faux burl wood paint technique on a smaller scale, I’ll report back if I can get it to look right!
html:
Burl wood is a unique yet recognizable pattern that’s trending in design. Burl wood has been used in antiques for centuries but is captivating interior designers and furniture makers yet again, popping up everywhere in retail and in the online marketplace.

burl wood media console

Burl wood has a distinct appearance, it originates inside a tree’s growth, known as a burl, that forms on the trunk or branches of a tree. These growths occur when the tree undergoes stress or injury, such as from a virus, fungus, or physical damage.

As a result, the grain patterns in burl wood are twisted and intricate forming often unpredictable designs prized for their aesthetic qualities. These patterns can range from swirls and eyes to waves and knots, making each piece of burl wood one of a kind.

burl wood side table 

Burl wood can be harvested from a variety of tree species, including walnut, maple, oak, redwood, and elm. Each type of wood offers its own unique color and grain characteristics, further adding to the material’s allure.

burl wood chest of drawers

Historically, burl wood has been a desirable material in the creation of fine furniture and decorative objects. During the 18th and 19th centuries, it was particularly popular in Europe, where it was used to create luxurious furniture pieces for the wealthy. Craftsman of that day would use veneers of burl wood to adorn cabinets and tables since the intricate grain patterns were a mark of sophistication and status. The use of burl wood extended to China and beyond, in the Far East it was harmonious with the principles of organic forms and nature.

In the antiques arena, burl wood pieces are pricey and sought after by collectors for their historical significance and unique beauty. The rarity of burl wood, combined with the skill required to work with it, makes antique burl wood pieces particularly valuable.

three drawer dresser

Burl wood has made a comeback in modern interiors. As the appeal of using organic materials continues to grow, so does the appreciation for craftsmanship and the use of natural materials in creating statement pieces.

burl wood coffee table

Furniture continues to be one of the most popular uses of burl wood to create eye catching focal points in living spaces, larger pieces can fetch high prices.

burl wood dresser

The ability of burl wood to seamlessly blend with both modern and traditional aesthetics makes it a versatile choice for a wide range of design styles.

parsons console

Because burl wood is often harvested from trees that are already damaged or diseased, its use does not contribute to deforestation so it is valued for its sustainability. Burl wood offers both craftsmanship and rarity which makes it a material that feels special, distinctive, and timeless.

rounded corner desk

burl wood box

I love burl wood, but its price point is high and I’m not in the market for any pieces at this time. I’m going to experiment with a faux burl wood paint technique on a smaller scale, I’ll report back if I can get it to look right!
